unnormalised: **Telecom Sector Sees Surge in OTT Partnerships**
normalised: **Telecom Sector Sees Surge in O T T Partnerships**

unnormalised: New Delhi, India – Telecom operators in India are increasingly forging partnerships with Over-The-Top (OTT) platforms to enhance their service offerings and capture a larger share of the digital entertainment market. Bharti Airtel recently announced a bundled plan with Zee5, offering subscribers premium content alongside high-speed data.
normalised: New Delhi, India – Telecom operators in India are increasingly forging partnerships with Over-The-Top (O T T) platforms to enhance their service offerings and capture a larger share of the digital entertainment market. Bharti Airtel recently announced a bundled plan with Zee five, offering subscribers premium content alongside high-speed data.

unnormalised: Reliance Jio continues its aggressive strategy, reportedly in talks with Disney+ Hotstar for a similar collaboration aimed at boosting subscriber retention. According to Dr. Meena Iyer, a telecom analyst at the IIM Ahmedabad, these partnerships allow operators to offer value-added services and differentiate themselves in a highly competitive landscape.

According to Doctor Meena Iyer, a telecom analyst at the I I M Ahmedabad, these partnerships allow operators to offer value-added services and differentiate themselves in a highly competitive landscape.

unnormalised: This trend is also benefiting regional players. For example, Vodafone Idea (Vi) has partnered with smaller OTT platforms specializing in regional languages to tap into the diverse entertainment preferences across India. Analysts estimate that revenue from such partnerships could add Rs. 500 crore to the sector’s earnings this fiscal year. The move also supports expansion of OTTs to Tier 2 and Tier 3 cities, increasing reach and potential viewership in areas underserved so far with limited infrastructure. Some partnerships even include joint marketing initiatives covering over 10,000 sq ft. of retail space.
